Although Everett takes the basic plot points and important characters and brings them into this book, I believe that calling this novel a retelling does it a disservice. James' story is much darker, sadder, and more intimate. It is a somber story of racism and slavery, and not a boys' adventure. In this book we get to understand the realities of life as a slave; the emotional impact of language, cruelty, abuse and incessant worry. There is a bit of humor, but in that area this book doesn't live up to the original. That did not ruin the story in any way, as I found this story to be more mature and that the emotion was evocative and true. Near the end of the story, I cried.Some of my favorite moments were the quiet, intelligent conversations between James & Huck, which were deep and meaningful. James was teaching Huck to see the world in a completely new way, letting the boy realize that slaves are people with the same thoughts, desires and emotions as the white people who owned them. The men continued to progress through the ranks, and received all the best stories, while the women were forced to write about arts and culture. It was a wonderful job that allowed me to travel around the world. It was also a difficult one as I was breaking into a world that had only admitted men. They convinced young men to have hope, and sat with them as they died. They did all of this while also in danger of sexual assault by the men they worked with, and often needed men they trusted to escort them around their own base. As the shockwaves rumbled through the city, buildings collapsed while people tried to find places of safety. Flames consumed the city for days, and unfortunately the city was completely unprepared. It is a book about social justice, told in the most unique fashion. The writing is brilliant, and I am putting this one on my desired short-list for the Aspen Words Literary Prize.The story concerns the commercially successful Criminal Action Penal Entertainment program (CAPE), which allows convicted murderers to earn their way out of prison... Each prisoner or link, is part of a chain, and they fight in death matches with links in other chains. The story is brutal. These men and women are televised fighting for their lives. It is blood sport, in the most vivid, and gruesome way. The country is obsessed with the sport, packing stadiums to watch, and the prisons are making large sums of money. To make it worse, they keep changing the rules.The victorious links rise through the ranks of their chain, in the hopes that they will eventually earn freedom.The two most popular prisoners/fighters are Loretta Thruwar and Hamara Stacker. They are on the same chain, and are lovers as well as teammates. Thurwar is only a few wins away from freedom, unless that rule changes like so many others.It is impossible to read this book without thinking about the state of our prison system. The violence is shocking, sad and inhumane, and it makes the reader contemplate the ways we ignore, out of negligence or intent, the brutality and savage nature of the prison system. It becomes impossible to avoid the realization that there are people living in cages, fighting for sustenance, lonely, frightened, and lacking in all of the things that make humans human. The characters are toys to all of those who are gaining power, prominence and riches off their lives, much like prisoners are today.The book is hard to take, in that it depicts violence so openly. review: If you do not know who Dickey Chapelle is, you should. If you haven't heard about her extraordinary life, blame your teachers, parents and text books.If you do not know who Dickey Chapelle is, you should. If you haven't heard about her extraordinary life, blame your teachers, parents and text books. This woman was an intelligent and interesting human who broke all the rules and created a safer space for all the women who came after her. Thank you Lorissa Rinehart for writing this book! It is inspirational, moving and I loved learning more about this remarkable woman.Dickey Chapelle was a war correspondent. A small woman, carrying her camera into the most dangerous places, decked out in cats-eye glasses, pearl earrings, and military fatigue. During WWII she jumped onto the open ship's deck to capture a photo of the Japanese bomber aiming for the ship. She took photos of doctors and nurses giving their own blood in order to encourage those back home to give more. During Vietnam she walked the jungles with the toughest marines.And between these wars you could find her in Cuba during their internal war, or in Algeria where they were fighting for independence from the French. She witnessed the infestation of locusts in the Middle East, and documented the failure of the west to offer any real aid. She went to India where she documented the ways American tractors impacted farming. In Hungary she reported on the Hungarian Revolution, where she was arrested and imprisoned, tortured physically and emotionally.She lived her life telling the stories and arguing that women were best suited for the job. She told military leaders that only a woman could tell the story to the women back home, because men would never understand how to reach into their hearts. She lived her life at war, with only a camera as protection. Dickey didn't just write the stories. She shared her heart. She cared, and it showed in her stories.And, still, very few people know her name. She has been mostly forgotten.
